data.title: Move "Fold all" menu entry to above the "Unfold all" entry (Issue #13262)
data.body: Moved "Fold all" menu entry to above the "Unfold all" and the separator.

data.title: Uncaught Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, lstat '/usr/share/atom'
data.body:
[Enter steps to reproduce below:]

1. ...
2. ...

**Atom Version**: 1.12.4
**Electron Version**: 1.3.9
**System**: Ubuntu 16.04.1
**Thrown From**: Atom Core


### Stack Trace

Uncaught Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, lstat '/usr/share/atom'

```
At fs.js:982

data.title: Fix prepending multiple gutters at once
data.body:
There's a bug when multiple gutters are prepended at once where their order is not correctly preserved in the dom. The issue is that we do not update indexInOldGutters even though we inserted a dom node in the old gutters dom.

Honestly, I'm unconvinced that this entire logic is correct, but this fixes the use case we have in Nuclide so it's more correct than before :)

Released under CC0

data.body:
I am running MacOSX.
After starting i am greeted by: The editor has crashed.
This is the log from the Console-app: https://gist.github.com/LeanderK/767c8e1166bea86255f04dad8bbdda25.
Running in safe-mode works.
```
atom version:
Atom    : 1.12.4
Electron: 1.3.9
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

```
apm --version
apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.10.2
```
I may be possible that an package caused this.

data.title: Syntax Highlighting breaks after certain length of line
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [ ] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [ ] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [ ] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [ ] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [ ] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.

### Description

If a line exceeds a certain length, syntax highlighting stops working.
I'm not sure where to report this bug, is this something the language (in this case Lua) module has to fix or the editor itself? 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. [First Step]
Create a new file
2. [Second Step]
Example code
```
zoneIDs.SpeciesToZoneId = {
[1755]={[1014]=1014}, -- Plump Jelly
	[1233]={[782]=782}, -- Pocket Reaver
	[1200]={[930]=930}, -- Pygmy Direhorn
	[1907]={[1018]=1018}, -- Pygmy Owl
	[378]={[181]=181,[475]=475,[510]=510,[42]=42,[27]=27,[34]=34,[30]=30,[462]=462,[121]=121,[1024]=1024,[24]=24,[491]=491,[241]=241,[606]=606,[9]=9,[950]=950,[36]=36,[480]=480,[21]=21,[81]=81,[301]=301,[20]=20,[22]=22,[39]=39,[40]=40}, -- Rabbit
	[237]={[201]=201}, -- Ravasaur Hatchling
	[238]={[40]=40}, -- Razormaw Hatchling
}
```
3. [and so on...]

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
Syntax highlighting works as expected
**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
Syntax highlighting breaks
http://i.imgur.com/wGRnPTf.png


### Versions

Atom    : 1.14.0-dev-87e6776
Electron: 1.3.6
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.3.0

Windows 8.1 x64

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

data.title: Use ctrl-shift-f5 to reload on Win/Linux
data.body:
This rebinds `windows:reload` command to <kbd>ctrl</kbd><kbd>shift</kbd><kbd>f5</kbd> on Windows and Linux to avoid conflicts with SymbolView package. 

Fixes #13267

data.title: Window reload key unusable in v1.13.0-beta4
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

### Description

The `window:reload` keybind is being overridden by `symbols-view:toggle-project-symbols` now as it's selector (`.platform-win32, .platform-linux`) is more specific than the one on `window:reload` (`body`).

This is due to the changes introduced in https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/13246.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Press <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>Shift</kbd>+<kbd>R</kbd> to try to reload the window.

**Expected behavior:**

Window reloads.

**Actual behavior:**

Symbols view menu loads.

### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

```
Atom    : 1.13.0-beta4
Electron: 1.3.9
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
apm  1.14.1
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.10.1.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

Windows 10 x64
US Keyboard

data.title: Flush DOM before displaying context menu
data.body:
Electron has an issue where displaying the context menu pauses the rendering loop. https://github.com/electron/electron/issues/1854

One unfortunate side effect is that when you right click on an element, the dom mutations to highlight the element have not been flushed yet which makes for a very bad user experience https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/2991

In order to solve this issue, we would like to flush the mutations and only then display the menu. Unfortunately, electron doesn't have APIs for that.

Things I have tried:
1) Electron has `browserWindow.webContents.invalidate()` and `.on('paint' -> ...)` but it only works with offscreen rendering which     atom doesn't use.
2) `.capturePage(-> ...)` takes a screenshot of the page and I hoped it     would do a flush first but it inconsistently displays the highlight     so it won't work.
3) `Using setTimeout((-> ...), 16)` works many times but not always
4) `requestAnimationFrame(-> ...)` should be what we want but unfortunately     it doesn't always show the highlights :(

What I found worked was to nest three `requestAnimationFrame`, it works all the time even when my machine is busy. This is not a 100% solution but I think that it's okay to assume that if the highlight hasn't been updated in three frames then you should probably try and optimize your code. 3 frames is 50ms and that delay isn't noticeable.

Note: the proper way to solve this that was mentioned in the issue is to open the menu from the main process but this is already what atom does and it's still an issue.

Before:
![](http://g.recordit.co/DruDVLJoN9.gif)

After:
![](http://g.recordit.co/PxBnwNt5yy.gif)

Released under CC0

data.title: Scrollbars move to the top of the file when splitting panes or closing split panes
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.

### Description

- When I open a large file and move the cursor to the bottom, and then click View->Panes->Split Right.
I found the scroll bar position of previous pane rewind to the top but the cursor is still on the last line.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Start Atom using `atom --safe` from `cmd.exe`
2. Open any file and resize the Atom window so you have a vertical scrollbar visible
3. Scroll to the middle of an opened file
4. Run `pane:split-right-and-copy-active-item`
5. Expected: The scrollbars to stay in the same position for both files. Actual: The scrollbars in both files moves to the top of the file
6. Close the right pane
7. Expected: The scrollbar position of the first file to not change. Actual: The scrollbar in the first file is displayed at the top of the file.

![scrollbar](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1058982/20443729/5a67cab4-adce-11e6-821b-b1784f161afc.gif)

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
scroll bar position should no change

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
I found the scroll bar position of previous pane rewind to the top but the cursor is still on the last line.


### Versions
Atom    : 1.12.0
Electron: 1.3.6
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.3.0

![atom-2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3035071/20433492/c8b1edc8-adde-11e6-9ede-f003873eaaf8.png)

data.title: Please slow down the development progress and get the bugs fixed
data.body:
Please, I encounter 3-4 different bugs in daily use 

I have recommended atom to my friends, it runs really slow in some of their laptops (mac & windows)
my friend's laptop has better hardware but I don't know why atom runs slower in it.
but it's okay in my computer, 

They ask me why, I just can't answer their questions.

I have reported some bugs about scroll bar in atom-light-ui and other ui issues on windows,
But it never get fixed from versions to versions, but the ticket was closed because 
they assumed it was fixed but still a problem in 1.12.0.

In the comment areas of every news/articles about atom, some people say good, while many people complain performance, or encountered other problems.

please slow down, and take a look at these plenty bugs

quality is nearly out of control now

data.title: First dead key not working in editor
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.

### Description

The first dead key used in the editor will ignore its first keystroke.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Use a fresh install of Atom
2. Set Windows' keyboard mode to United States-International (preferably while using a keyboard with the same layout)
3. <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>N</kbd> to get a new file.
4. <kbd>Shift</kbd> + <kbd>"</kbd> then <kbd>Space</kbd>

**Expected behavior:**

A double quotation mark character `"` should be inserted.

**Actual behavior:**

A space character ` ` was inserted. When repeating step 4 after this a double quotation mark character is inserted as expected. This issue will not occur again in the same window unless it is reloaded or Atom is restarted.

### Versions

- Atom 1.12.4
- Electron 1.3.9
- Chrome 52.0.2743.82
- Node 6.5.0
- Windows 7 Enterprise SP1 x64
- Windows 10 (1611?) x64

data.title: Move "Fold all" menu entry to above the "Unfold all" entry
data.body: In the Edit > Folding menu, it would make sense, to match Fold/Unfold entries, that "Fold All"/"Unfold All" were also paired, above the separator. Like so: ### Versions ``` $ atom --version Atom : 1.12.4 Electron: 1.3.9 Chrome : 52.0.2743.82 Node : 6.5.0 $ apm --version apm 1.12.9 npm 3.10.5 node 4.4.5 python 2.7.11 git 2.5.4 $ sw_vers ProductName: Mac OS X ProductVersion: 10.10.5 BuildVersion: 14F2009 ```

    at Function.Module._load (module.js:441:3)
    at Module.runMain (module.js:607:10)
    at run (bootstrap_node.js:382:7)
npm ERR! Linux 4.8.8-zen-gb9f2356-dirty

```

related: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/13173

fails on 1.13 beta 4 after node 7 support fix was merged, maybe that issue is different

data.title: Stopped working on my Macbook Pro
data.body: I'm not sure what's going on but when I restarted my Macbook Pro Atom windows wouldn't open.  An error box popped up saying: The editor has crashed Please report this issue to https://github.com/atom/atom. I know it is up to date because I am very diligent about that sort of thing. I even went as far as downloading Atom again from the Atom website, deleted my current version and tried replacing it with the newly downloaded version. I got the same message. Any help would be GREATLY appreciated as I use ATOM daily! (I really like Atom and I don't want to have to switch to another text editor.)

data.title: Code folds are not restored after closing Atom
data.body:
I am finding that after closing Atom and re-opening my session and tabs are restored by code folds are not.

I am writing a lot of functions and I do not need to see all of my code all the time so I depend on code folding to make things manageable.

Code folding does not make things easier for me if I have to go through and re-close every function each time I open Atom before I can begin.

Should folds be remembered? I can't see any mention of this in the documentation so I am not sure if it is a bug or a missing feature.

I am aware of the remember-folds package but this only saves folds when opening and closing tabs - not closing and restoring Atom.

data.title: Package install fails because the install directory is deleted
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [ ] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
I reported this to https://github.com/atom/apm/issues/648 as well.
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

### Description

We are running into big issues in Hydrogen because the install directory get's deleted before the package is fully installed. This doesn't happen on every system and it shouldn't be a package specific problem. We'd really appreciate your help.

Here is the full log: [hydrogen-install.log.zip](https://github.com/nteract/hydrogen/files/596086/hydrogen-install.log.zip)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. `apm install hydrogen`

**Expected behavior:**

Hydrogen installs successfully.

**Actual behavior:**

The installation aborts half way, because the temporary directory is deleted before the installation finished.

### Versions

```
$ apm --version
apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.10.2
```
This isn't a operating specific problem. We have reports about this on Windows, Linux and Mac OS X.

data.title: Package settings Keybindings disappear after unchecking Enable box
data.body:
### Description

When the **Enable** box in a package's **Keybindings** section is un-checked and Atom is re-started, the **Keybindings** section disappears, making it impossible to re-enable the package's default keybindings by checking the **Enable** box.

### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Uncheck the **Enable** box in a package's **Keybindings** settings (e.g. the bracket-matcher package).
2. Re-start Atom.
3. Notice that the **Keybindings** settings section has completely disappeared from the package's settings; therefore, there is no way to re-enable the package's **Keybindings** by re-checking the **Enable** box, because there is no **Enable** box to check.

**Expected behavior:**

After unchecking the **Enable** box in the packages **Keybindings** section and re-starting Atom, it should still be possible to see the **Keybindings** section with an un-checked **Enable** box.

**Actual behavior:**

On the package's settings page there is no longer a **Keybindings** section between the **Settings** section and the **README** section.

**Workaround:**

Edit the Atom config file and remove the entry for the package from the `packagesWithKeymapsDisabled` section.

### Versions

On Ubuntu:

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.11.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```

```
$ apm --version
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4

```
On Windows:

```
atom --version
Atom    : 1.12.2
Electron: 1.3.6
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.3.0
```

```
apm --version
INFO: Could not find files for the given pattern(s).
The system cannot find the file specified.
apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python
git
visual studio
```

data.title: Remove atom-space-pen-views and custom elements from bundled packages
data.body:
Refs: #13253 

In order to snapshot bundled packages we need to remove eval time interactions with DOM APIs. The two biggest offenders in this regard are jQuery (which is required by `atom-space-pen-views`) and HTML custom elements. The issues with jQuery *could* be addressed by patching jQuery to not do feature detection, but considering that we want to remove it anyway over the long term and it causes other performance and complexity problems, it's probably cleaner to just remove jQuery completely. Custom elements were a failed experiment and we aren't actually getting value out of registering them with the DOM global. They can be replaced with plain JS objects managing a DOM element.

### Affected packages

* [x] Atom Core: Reopen Project (https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/13375)
* [x] archive-view (https://github.com/atom/archive-view/pull/45)
* [x] autocomplete-plus (https://github.com/atom/autocomplete-plus/pull/826)
* [x] bookmarks (https://github.com/atom/bookmarks/pull/76)
* [x] command-palette (https://github.com/atom/command-palette/pull/75)
* [x] deprecation-cop (https://github.com/atom/deprecation-cop/pull/72)
* [x] encoding-selector (https://github.com/atom/encoding-selector/pull/38)
* [x] find-and-replace @maxbrunsfeld (https://github.com/atom/find-and-replace/pull/838)
* [x] fuzzy-finder (https://github.com/atom/fuzzy-finder/pull/273)
* [x] git-diff (https://github.com/atom/git-diff/pull/119)
* [x] go-to-line (https://github.com/atom/go-to-line/pull/40)
* [x] grammar-selector (https://github.com/atom/grammar-selector/pull/35)
* [x] image-view (https://github.com/atom/image-view/pull/82)
* [x] keybinding-resolver (https://github.com/atom/keybinding-resolver/pull/46)
* [x] line-ending-selector (https://github.com/atom/line-ending-selector/pull/37)
* [x] markdown-preview (https://github.com/atom/markdown-preview/pull/456)
* [x] notifications (https://github.com/atom/notifications/pull/139, https://github.com/atom/notifications/pull/149)
* [x] package-generator (https://github.com/atom/package-generator/pull/48)
* [x] settings-view (https://github.com/atom/settings-view/pull/913)
* [x] snippets (https://github.com/atom/snippets/pull/233)
* [x] spell-check (https://github.com/atom/spell-check/pull/193)
* [x] status-bar (https://github.com/atom/status-bar/pull/178)
* [x] styleguide (https://github.com/atom/styleguide/pull/50)
* [x] symbols-view (https://github.com/atom/symbols-view/pull/211)
* [x] tabs (https://github.com/atom/tabs/pull/402)
* [x] timecop (https://github.com/atom/timecop/pull/23)
* [x] tree-view (https://github.com/atom/tree-view/pull/1032)
* [x] update-package-dependencies (https://github.com/atom/update-package-dependencies/pull/15)
* [x] welcome (https://github.com/atom/welcome/pull/56)
* [x] wrap-guide (https://github.com/atom/wrap-guide/pull/65)

data.title: Atom Startup Time
data.body:
The following is a summary of a CPU profile taken during startup. The aim of this issue is to explicitly state what the bottlenecks are and, where possible, suggest ideas on how to solve them. Profiles were taken after disabling all the 3rd party packages. * Bootstrap Node.
**Cost:** ~ 100ms.
**Savings:** N/A.
**Difficulty:** Medium/Hard. ![screen shot 2016-11-17 at 13 53 58](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/20390197/ff02edee-accd-11e6-890e-d5fbde25e2d9.png) This section involves setting up Node and is standard for all the projects. The bottom line is that it would require a change in Electron, hence why I chose Medium/Hard as the difficulty. It might be worth exploring solutions with the Electron team as well as talking to the Node team, understanding if there are plans to improve this in the future. An interesting observation is that most of it is spent in requiring modules, so maybe Electron/Node could employ some of the techniques we plan to use for userland requires (see below). * Requiring modules.
**Cost:** ~ 350-400 ms.
**Savings:** 90-100%.
**Difficulty:** Medium/Hard. This sections concerns the time spent in searching, compiling and executing JavaScript files. I haven't provided a screenshot of the CPU profile because this cost is spread across many function calls. So long as modules don't access Node core modules or DOM APIs at require-time, we should be able to use v8 snapshots to do most of the work during `script/build`. This means we would need to restructure some packages to stop using those APIs, but it should be doable. Last week we have been working on proving the feasibility of this approach and it seems like we could apply it to Atom. * Constructing `AtomEnvironment`.
**Cost:** ~ 100-110ms.
**Savings:** 75-80%.
**Difficulty:** Medium. ![screen shot 2016-11-17 at 14 08 52](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/20390488/6c9aceca-accf-11e6-8630-5da169a2a984.png) The above chart breaks down into several sub-tasks. Some of them can be executed upfront in the snapshotting phase: * Creating objects like `Workspace`, `TextEditorRegistry`, etc.(~ 10ms). * `Config.setSchema` (~ 7ms). * `ThemeManager.loadBaseStylesheets` (~ 19ms). * `KeymapManager.loadBundledKeymaps` (~ 11ms) Others need to happen at runtime, although we can make them asynchronous and avoid blocking the main thread: * `ApplicationDelegate.disableZoom` (~ 9ms). * `AtomEnvironment.registerDefaultCommands` (~ 7ms). * `AtomEnvironment.installWindowEventHandler` (~ 7ms). * `HistoryManager.loadState` (~ 25ms). * `Config.loadUserConfig` (~ 5ms). * Loading Packages.
**Cost:** ~ 50-60ms.
**Savings:** 90-100%.
**Difficulty:** Medium. ![screen shot 2016-11-17 at 13 15 15](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/20390867/f4c94866-acd0-11e6-8626-bff3f7d54513.png) Loading packages involves reading their style sheets and their configuration schemas. The image above is the typical chart of a single `Package.load` call. At least for bundled packages, we have all the information at compile-time and we should be able to bake it into the snapshot. * Environment Deserialization.
**Cost:** ~ 50-60ms.
**Savings:** 70%.
**Difficulty:** N/A. ![screen shot 2016-11-17 at 13 16 21](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/20391116/463b8d7a-acd2-11e6-9e05-4077e194acb9.png) Deserializing the environment is something that needs to happen at runtime but, as the chart above shows, the dominator in that stack trace is `GitRepository`. In particular, it might be worth revisiting `openSubmodules` and `refreshStatus`: the former can probably be deferred at a later moment in time, while the latter is already asynchronous and is probably slow because of the overhead of creating a `Task`. * Activating Packages.
**Cost:** ~ 300ms.
**Savings:** N/A
**Difficulty:** Medium/Hard. ![screen shot 2016-11-17 at 14 39 47](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/20391597/6a1adc30-acd4-11e6-93bf-aa929f773678.png) Estimating savings for this section is somewhat tricky, as a considerable amount of time is spent in requiring modules (which has been accounted for in a previous section). However, we think we could further reduce the cost of it by splitting core packages activation into two phases (snapshot and runtime), offloading as much work as possible to the snapshot one. * Refreshing less cache and reloading base style sheets.
**Cost:** ~ 20ms.
**Savings:** 90-100%
**Difficulty:** N/A. ![screen shot 2016-11-17 at 14 55 48](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/20391951/04a732c0-acd6-11e6-9e21-41c2bd840d7c.png) The first thing that is suspicious is that this stack trace feels redundant, as we do a similar thing when instantiating `AtomEnvironment`. Anyways, this is all information we have at compile time, so the only cost we should pay at runtime is to add the proper CSS to the `` element. * First Layout
**Cost:** ~ 250ms.
**Savings:** N/A
**Difficulty:** Hard. ![screen shot 2016-11-17 at 14 59 03](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/20392134/c837d6e0-acd6-11e6-8404-97abc06feaf1.png) This is the first layout that Atom performs after loading and it takes a pretty huge amount of time. Unfortunately, we cannot inspect what is happening under the hood that causes this layout to be slow. We suspect it might be due to our use of flexbox, but at the same time we feel like it might be worth capturing a native profile of Electron and inspecting the actual native calls that are being executed. * Main Process.
**Cost:** ~ 600ms.
**Savings:** N/A
**Difficulty:** N/A. Profiling the main process is somewhat trickier than profiling the renderer process, as we don't have direct access to the dev tools. However, I have estimated that we spend `~ 600ms` to get from the first line of code in the main process to the first line of code in the renderer process. This section probably deserves an entire issue, as we are aware that the main process needs a overhaul. However it's worth noting that it significantly contributes to startup time, although it's unclear how much of it is Atom's fault and how much of it is due to Electron. /cc: @atom/maintainers

data.title: [FIXED] Atom appears to open past monitor. JRE 8u112 update
data.body:
### Prerequisites
Checked, nothing related.

### Description
I just updated to JRE 8u112, and Atom fails to open, the window looks to opening past my current screens, the atom window is visible as it expands to fill the screen, but carries on beyond the furthest right monitor.

Uninstalled and reinstalled, updated to latest atom.

System:
Windows 7 Pro
AMD FirePro W4300
2x Monitors

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Installed JRE 8u112
2. Open Atom
3. Looked confused

### Expected behavior
Opens to a current monitor

### Actual behavior
Opens beyond furthest right monitor

### Versions
Atom 1.11.2 - version that I was using
Atom 1.12.3 - version I am updated too after problem started.

JRE 8u102 - version that I was using
JRE 8u112 - update

data.title: Upgrade Electron from 1.3.6 to 1.3.9
data.body:
- Upgrade Node to 6.5.0 - solves mapped drives on Windows resolving to SMB path #13104
- Fix accessibility always enabled on touch screen https://github.com/electron/electron/pull/7611
- Fix window.opener API not behaving as expected

data.title: Remap ctrl-alt-letter key bindings on Win32
data.body:
because they conflict on international keyboards. Changes;

- `window:reload` is now <kbd>ctrl</kbd><kbd>shift</kbd><kbd>r</kbd>
- `window:run-package-specs` is now <kbd>ctrl</kbd><kbd>shift</kbd><kbd>y</kbd>
- `application:add-project-folder` is now <kbd>ctrl</kbd><kbd>shift</kbd><kbd>a</kbd>
- `editor:log-cursor-scope` is no longer bound by default (it was there for Sublime parity but we can't match it so any remapping would not be parity)

Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom-keymap/issues/175#

data.title: Upgrade Electron from 1.3.6 to 1.3.7
data.body: Brings in Node 6.5.0 which solves #13104
